results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of a somewhat nostalgic version of Australian suburban family life as it was in the 50s and early 60s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 children playing with sprinkler and toys 1950s
00:02:19:00 leaving hospital with baby
00:03:39:00 a 1950s Christmas scene; children with toys
00:04:59:00 brief shot of Queenscliff with kids riding in Cobb & Co. horse-drawn carriage
00:06:53:00 girl jumping on a trampoline with pier in the background – trampoline park with interesting “trampolines” sign
00:08:59:00 nice shot of toddler waddling towards the camera
00:12:54:00 backyard children’s birthday party
00:17:05:00 young girl using a hula hoop in a paddock
00:18:02:00 toddler gets a home haircut

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes of families on holidays at the beach and the snow, along with suburban backyard activities,children’s parties, and some interesting glimpses of country Victoria in the 1970s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

00:00:48:00 exterior scenes of ski lodge with children in front
00:01:13:00 children snowball play

00:02:29:00 close-up of 70s ski fashion
00:02:52:00 warm colours and well-lit fashion on ski slope
00:03:02:00 sit down ski lift
00:03:13:00 good close-up shot of man and child catching a seated ski lift; man wearing fashionable sunglasses from the era
00:03:25:00 some nice tracking shots taken while on the ski lift
00:03:53:00 man and child on ski lift – 70s fashion and hair
00:04:36:00 backyard children’s birthday party with costumes, balloons, bikes, trampoline, party, games
00:04:56:00 musical chairs and pass the parcel outside
00:05:47:00 backyard cricket
00:06:05:00 close-up women’s 70s fashion
00:06:14:00 purple Ford Fairlane in front yard with BP sign in the background
00:06:21:00 nice close-up of Ford Fairlane
00:06:32:00 children eating BBQ
00:06:43:00 child playing and jumping with “Space Hopper”
00:08:08:00 street parade with child riding a bike while in blackface – Ballarat 1974
00:08:39:00 interesting filming from inside a marching band while marching in parade
00:11:25:00 slow-motion reverse footage of kids falling “IN” to a rubber dingy from water
00:11:45:00 interesting moving shot of seagulls jumping from a pier
00:12:28:00 nice shot of child eating pastie and drinking Coke in front of old Sorrento front beach kiosk
00:14:03:00 nice beach scene with colourful umbrella and 70s beach fashion

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film has two sequences. Firstly, a debutante ball circa 1960s, where we see the very nervous young couples as they descend a staircase to be introduced to the committee of older people overseeing the proceedings. Jack captures the rigorous nature of a debutante presentation with its strict dress code and rules, and somewhat stultifying atmosphere.

Secondly, Jack captures entertainment at an ice rink that includes several different acts.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected hightlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards, ‘Vegas News 70’ and ‘Delighted Debutants’ (sic)
00:00:18:00 the debutantes line up for a formal photograph with their flower posies in the shape of the Freemasons ‘square and compass’ symbol
00:00:39:00 organisers inspecting the debutantes where we see 1960s style hair styles held in place by hair spray
00:00:60:00 dignitories enter the ball in a parade and the women are presented with flower posies as they line up on the stage ready for the debutantes presentation
00:01:32:00 two children appear as mascots, slightly confused
00:01:53:00 the first of the young women debutantes, in their white formal ball dresses, appear on the stage with their partners, young men in formal evening suits
00:02:43:00 negotiating the stairs, no hands on the rails
00:02:58:00 the curtsy and the bow to the dignitories
00:03:54:00 the musicians
00:04:28:00 the Freemasons society symbol above the dancers
00:05:03:00 members of the band playing their instruments
00:05:35:00 stepping through a particularly painstaking dance
00:06:25:00 the formalities over, debutantes and their partners relax at the tables in the ballroom
00:07:00:00 the brass section of the band
00:07:07:00 dancing what appears to be the ‘Pride of Erin’ waltz
00:07:46:00 various skaters performing on ice
00:09:37:00 two ice skaters dressed in a cow costume
00:12:18:00 an ice skater leaping through a ring of fire

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a school for children with special needs. We see the children undertaking classroom activities and hear interviews with the teachers.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 children sit on the floor ready to play musical instruments followed by views of the children enjoying playing with the instruments
00:00:32:00 interview with a teacher discussing the lessons children are involved in that day
00:01:50:00 one of the teachers addresses the camera directly to discuss future plans for the school
00:02:24:00 the children take part in a shopping expedition
00:02:36:00 painting at easels
00:03:49:00 activities with the grocery items bought earlier
00:04:14:00 individual lesson in shopping for a teenager

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s. A feature of the parade is the Radio Cabs entry which is a car covered in paper flowers. The Radio Cabs company in Ballarat was started by the film maker and his family and friends.

This film contains scenes from a street parade in Ballarat in regional Victoria during the 1940s or 1950s. The parade is in the style of the era - featuring floats made by and promoting local groups and businesses, government departments and marching bands.

Another feature is a large street march of citizens concerned with world peace, conscription, suppression of Aboriginal people, workers rights, keeping prices down and the atom bomb. It is interesting to note the large contingent of women marching in the parade and the professionally painted banners and placards.

Jack has also captured an exciting motorcycle grand prix at Ballarat which includes spectacular side car racing. Views of the races feature the motorcyclists on their 1940s and 1950s era motorbikes and in protective gear, the haybales used to secure the track, spills around corners and the enthusiastic crowds.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 a large crowd of spectators line up along Sturt St, Ballarat; the Carlyon Hotel can be seen in the background and period cars in the foreground
00:00:17:00 a horse and carriage laden with passengers dressed in historic costume follow a military band in a parade
00:00:24:00 a views down the historic streets of Ballarat and a women’s military band in the passing parade
00:00:47:00 participating floats
00:01:09:00 an air mail float from the Postmaster General’s Department
00:01:16:00 Easter bunny float
00:01:35:00 the Ballarat Scottish Pipe Band followed by a yellow Vauxhall Vyvern model sports car
00:01:50:00 floats pass by including one marking Australian Chinese history in the area
00:03:01:00 an historic and comedic fire brigade float
00:03:31:00 preparing the Radio Cabs float followed by views of the decorated car driving through Ballarat traffic
00:05:14:00 a truck carries a train steam engine in the parade, against a backdrop of Ballarat shops
00:05:32:00 spectators clap and wave as the the Radio Cabs float goes by in the parade
00:05:49:00 title card ‘Children make a colourful display - Ballarat Victoria News Review’
00:07:03:00 spectators at a recreation oval watch large groups of school children marching and performing dances
00:08:51:00 a fair or agricultural show with carnival rides and sideshow tents (possibly the Ballarat Show)
00:09:14:00 an aerial display overhead
00:10:00:00 farm machinery on display
00:10:10:00 a march for peace and other issues in Sydney
00:10:34:00 a large truck festooned with signs such as, ‘Demand World Peace’, ‘Union Leaders Jailed’ and ‘Aborigines Suppressed’
00:10:59:00 a glimpse of the sign for ‘New Theatre’
00:12:30:00 a dramatic fire of a large house or apartment building
00:13:50:00 interview with a motorcyclist followed by racing
00:14:53:00 signs ‘TT Motor Cycles Do Over 100 M.P.H. and ‘1950 Victorian Grand Prix Ballarat’
00:15:16:00 motorcycle riders take off in a race followed by views of the race around the track
00:15:44:00 several riders come to grief on a bend followed by scenes of the race and the crowd of spectators
00:16:51:00 riding over a wet track
00:17:20:00 the track in more open areas
00:18:05:00 sidercar racing
00:18:49:00 Norton model motor bike with side car
00:19:00:00 scenes of the races
00:20:47:00 title card ‘The End’

00:01:22:00 a man gestures to the camera that he has lost his bet

00:02:15:00 a travelling tram, tram tracks, cars and trucks on Ballarat streets, including Sturt Street

00:02:30:00 two men walking around a turbulent waterway
00:03:03:00 Ballarat rooftops from a high vantage point
00:03:50:00 Ballarat street scene focussing on some people walking toward the camera wearing good examples of fashionable 1940s style clothes
00:04:08:00 Ballarat Town Hall
00:04:10:00 a main shopping street in Ballarat showing a ‘Myer Store’ verandah

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

Films aren’t just for entertainment – they can document experiences, transport us to other worlds or act as windows into the past. The home movie collection of amateur filmmaker Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890–1968) is all three.

Did you know that there was an outdoor Olympic pool across the train tracks from where Fed Square now sits in the 40s? How about the high-octane car race the Templestowe Hill Climb, which snaked through 960 metres of outer suburb scrub?

Thanks to Kenneth’s granddaughter, who donated his films to our collection in August 2016, we can peer back into Melbourne’s past, sharing everyday and extraordinary experiences.

Comprising 38 cans of silent, colour 16mm films, Kenneth’s collection portrays gardens, regional and interstate holidays, beauty pageants, shipping ports, water skiing and royal visits, many of the films introduced by his custom-made title, “KenRa Films Present”. No surprise for a celluloid enthusiast who had a movie studio behind his Caulfield home.

Kenneth even came third in a Western Australian amateur film competition for Every Many Should Have A Hobby, a fictional narrative of a man pursuing his secret filmmaking passion. The film is currently undergoing conservation treatment due to acetate deterioration, but we’re hoping to get it digitised like the wonderful home movies in this collection.

Comprising 38 cans of silent, colour 16mm films, Kenneth’s collection portrays gardens, regional and interstate holidays, beauty pageants, shipping ports, water skiing and royal visits, many of the films introduced by his custom-made title, “KenRa Films Present”. No surprise for a celluloid enthusiast who had a movie studio behind his Caulfield home.

Kenneth even came third in a Western Australian amateur film competition for Every Many Should Have A Hobby, a fictional narrative of a man pursuing his secret filmmaking passion. The film is currently undergoing conservation treatment due to acetate deterioration, but we’re hoping to get it digitised like the wonderful home movies in this collection.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is more whimsical in approach than the family based footage seen in other films, as reflected by the title ‘Open Road Open Sky’. In the opening scene we see Kenneth a fellow traveller wandering along country roads as well as shots of roads into the distance and the skies overhead. Further into the reel we see the Sherbrooke Forest, the ‘Burnham Beeches’ and ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’. There are shots of several animals such as emu and echidna as well as quite a bit of birdlife and Kenneth’s favourite shots of flowers and trees. The reel ends with Kenneth walking away from the forests and an end title shot.

Selected sequence list:

00:00:27:00 title ‘Open Road Open Sky’, Kenneth and a fellow traveller wandering along country roads.

00:01:00:00 large power poles along country roads, a few examples of country houses.

00:01:47:00 kangaroos and peacocks.

00:02:45:00 Kenneth walks along a road with his camera.

00:03:14:00 an emu, echidna and a wallaby come into view.

00:04:15:00 close up of Kenneth filming behind his camera followed by ‘Burnham Beeches’ mansion and estate in Sherbrooke Forest and the ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’.

00:06:31:00 birdlife inlcuding storks and lyrebirds.

00:07:44:00 Indigenous rider on horseback, waving at the camera whilst he rounds up horses, camels and Shetland ponies on grassland.

00:08:07:00 brolgas (filmed only from neck down only so difficult to be certain).

00:10:03:00 a quick shot of a woman behind the camera.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughte. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia, with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures a roadtrip to South Australia showing several ports and towns and the landscapes and ocean views along the way.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 title card ‘Exploring South Australia’ using a Shell (Gas and Oil) roadmap of SA
00:00:22:00 the Balmera Post Office with signs reading ‘Post and Telegraph Office’ and ‘Money Order and Commonwealth Savings Bank’
00:00:31:00 a town street with a large truck loaded with full hessian sacks followed by views of roses in the median strip gardens
00:01:32:00 Mrs Rankine holds some very large grapefruit
00:02:10:00 the travellers enjoy some public gardens
00:02:00:00 a ‘To Adelaide’ road sign on a flooded road, alongside some boats
00:03:20:00 filming from a punt that takes the travellers and cars across a waterway
00:05:00:00 sign reading ‘Port Augusta: Change here for Quorn Alice Springs’ followed by views of the rail station
00:05:20:00 street scenes with pedestrians, cars and buses
00:05:35:00 a long pipeline travels alongside a road in which Mrs Rankine, in a wonderful navy blue suit, sunglasses and cream ‘Maryjane’ style shoes, stands by the car taking in the views followed by two travellers on a motorcycle (motorbike)
00:06:13:00 the Whyalla Post Office followed by quiet street scenes including motorists and motorbike riders, an Orlando Wines advertising sign, lovely older buildings such as the Hotel Spencer and a great example of a 1940s or 1950s style small truck parked outside.
00:06:45:00 Mrs Rankine stands on a balcony of the hotel
00:06:57:00 a steam train carrying what appears to be aggregate crushed rock for road construction comes into view and shortly after, workers release the load into trackside rock and gravel piles, a fisherman and his bike on the pier and the rock being loaded onto the ship by way of a conveyor belt system
00:08:58:00 Mrs Rankine sits atop a very large pipeline, fanning flies away from her face
00:09:28:00 lengthy views of industrial works and cargo loading facilities
00:11:51:00 a lone blue-tongue lizard
00:12:18:00 the family car sits on top of a rise overlooking grassland and the sea, a ship, a town and in the foreground, an unusually low electricity pole and wiring
00:13:05:00 a ‘Port Lincoln’ sign on a building followed by scenes of the town, the bays, bobbing boats, public flowerbeds and 1940s and 1950s style cars, trucks and houses
00:14:53:00 the Pier Hotel with Mrs Rankine on a balcony and then in a window knitting with the blue and green sea in the background
00:15:15:00 scenes around the foreshore, out over the water, yachts, small boats and jettys and grassy shorelines
00:16:20:00 Mrs Rankine on shore in the blustery winds
00:16:55:00 a rail crossing on a sandy road with a ‘Commonwealth Roads’ sign warning of a ‘£50 penalty’
00:17:27:00 a wonderful ageing and long pier with a lighthouse at the end
00:17:42:00 a building bearing the name Port Pirie followed by views of the town and port, including a tugboat pulling a large ship into dock
00:18:15:00 another ship, named Pioneer Reef New York
00:18:18:00 a closer view of one of the tugboats followed by the Rankine family car parked on a dusty road
00:18:40:00 four big draught horses pulling a plough and then seven pulling a cultivator
00:19:07:00 Port Broughton Post Office with a sign for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and then the Hotel Broughton
00:19:25:00 Mrs Rankine sits on a seat outside the hotel in front of a stained glass window sign for the ‘Parlor’ (interestingly, the American version of spelling), which would have been the hotel’s ladies parlour when women were not allowed in the public bar of a hotel
00:19:44:00 the Point Broughton War Memorial
00:19:58:00 a friend with their cat
00:20:05:00 a roadsign for Port Victoria followed by son-in-law Bob Wootten and grandson on a pier, who then join Mrs Rankine and Bettye (Rankine) Wootten
00:20:55:00 sign for Kadina flashes by and a train carriage, named ‘Pelican’ which was part of the ‘Bluebird Railcars’ that travelled around South Australia at the time; passengers board the carriage while luggage is loaded from a truck parked alongside
00:21:29:00 Kenneth’s grandson in his stroller and some quick scenes around the town

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film Kenneth and some fellow travellers visit the Grampians showing the varied scenery across the mountainous ranges and the valley, groups of people relaxing and enjoying natural surrounds as well as hiking and gathering for a picnic.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title card ‘Our Grampians’ starts us off travelling along a country road where we see the sign to Halls Gap and other local towns, followed by a sign for “Hotel Bellfield” and a spot of golf.

00:00:02:00 ‘Splitter Falls’ sign appears ahead of more views of the mountainous range, roads and the valley below.
00:04:12:00 a very long waterfall.

00:04:57:00 a group of tourist overlooling the hills from a high vantage point.

00:05:13:00 a photographer setting up a spectacular looking shot of people sitting on rocks.

00:06:37:00 toasting bread on an open fire and the sign ‘New scenic track to McKenzie Falls’.

results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 7]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film Kenneth and some fellow travellers visit the Grampians showing the varied scenery across the mountainous ranges and the valley, groups of people relaxing and enjoying natural surrounds as well as hiking and gathering for a picnic.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title card ‘Our Grampians’ starts us off travelling along a country road where we see the sign to Halls Gap and other local towns, followed by a sign for “Hotel Bellfield” and a spot of golf.

00:00:02:00 ‘Splitter Falls’ sign appears ahead of more views of the mountainous range, roads and the valley below.
00:04:12:00 a very long waterfall.

00:04:57:00 a group of tourist overlooling the hills from a high vantage point.

00:05:13:00 a photographer setting up a spectacular looking shot of people sitting on rocks.

00:06:37:00 toasting bread on an open fire and the sign ‘New scenic track to McKenzie Falls’.

00:09:27:00 women holding a bunch of wildflowers one of whom sports a classic 40’s headscarf style.

00:10:21:00 we see a tree being prepared for felling by two mean using a double ended saw followed by a logging truck.

00:11:14:00 sign to ‘Wonderland’ followed by a large group of people trekking up a rocky incline, taking rests on the rocks, climbing narrow ravines and finally looking out from the top.

00:15:07:00 the travellers stand around a fire with a billy-can, cooking lambchops and bread.

00:17:12:00 a farmer and his tractor from a close view and pink tinged clouds.
